title: GuideCam: A Digital Camera with Picture Spots Finder
title_en: GuideCam: A Digital Camera with Picture Spots Finder
abstract: 本研究はデジタルカメラに写真スポット検索機能を統合する問題を扱っている。提案ではスマートフォンのGPSとオンライン写真共有サービスのジオタグ情報を組み合わせて地図上に撮影候補を表示し、Next/Prev操作や自動更新を含むユーザインタフェースで撮影候補を巡回提示する実装を示している。
abstract_en: This work addresses integrating a picture-spot finder into a digital camera. The proposal combines smartphone GPS and online photo-sharing service geotags to display candidate shooting locations on a map and uses a user interface with Next/Prev actions and automatic updates to cycle and present the candidates.
positioning_summary: 本研究はスマートフォン利用者が撮影場所を容易に見つけられないという課題に位置づけられている。位置づけとして本研究は消費者向けのGPS機器とオンラインの写真共有サービス間のジオタグの粗さや不足を補い、撮影者の発見性を高めることを狙っている。
positioning_summary_en: This research is positioned to address the problem that smartphone users have difficulty finding photo shooting locations. The positioning identifies gaps in consumer GPS devices and online photo-sharing geotags and aims to improve discoverability for photographers.
purpose_summary: 本研究の目的は撮影者に対して有用な撮影候補を提示して撮影の効率と発見性を向上させることである。目的として本研究はスマートフォンとオンライン写真データを活用して不足や粗いジオタグ情報を補完し、撮影候補の提示を行うことを目標としている。
purpose_summary_en: The purpose of this research is to improve shooting efficiency and discoverability by presenting useful candidate locations to photographers. The goal is to leverage smartphones and online photo data to compensate for missing or coarse geotag information and provide candidate suggestions.
method_summary: 本研究の方法は端末のGPS情報とオンライン写真共有サービスのジオタグ情報を取得して地図サービス上に撮影候補を表示することである。方法として本システムは取得したジオタグを地図上に表示し、Next/Prev操作や自動更新などのユーザインタフェースで候補を巡回提示する仕組みを実装している。
method_summary_en: The method of this research acquires device GPS and online photo-sharing geotag data and displays candidate shooting spots on a map service. The system implementation displays the collected geotags on a map and provides mechanisms such as Next/Prev actions and automatic updates in the user interface to cycle through candidates.
evaluation_summary: 本研究の評価はオンライン写真共有サービスのジオタグデータとスマートフォンのGPSデータを用いたジオタグ精度の分析に基づいて行われた。評価ではジオタグの位置ずれを数百メートルから数キロメートルの範囲で分析し、提案システムの候補提示と地図表示の挙動を確認した結果、ジオタグの粗さにより提示候補の位置精度に変動があることが示唆された。
evaluation_summary_en: The evaluation of this research was based on analyzing geotag accuracy using online photo-sharing geotag data and smartphone GPS data. The evaluation analyzed location offsets in the range of hundreds of meters to kilometers and inspected the candidate presentation and map display behavior of the proposed system, suggesting that geotag coarseness causes variability in candidate location accuracy.

paths: Information systems → Information systems applications → Spatial-temporal systems → Location based services
Human-centered computing → Visualization → Visualization application domains → Geographic visualization
Human-centered computing → Ubiquitous and mobile computing → Ubiquitous and mobile devices → Smartphones

rejected.reason: Not focused on image processing or computational photography techniques.
Interaction design aspects exist but are secondary to location and map functionality.
Paper is system/design focused, not primarily an empirical study.
GPS is a component, but the contribution is broader (location-based service integration).

prompt.system: You are an expert indexer who assigns ACM CCS 2012 concepts to computing research papers. You will receive the paper's title, abstract, and structured summaries. Use only the provided candidate concepts. Select at most 3 concepts that best describe the paper. If none of the candidates fit, return an empty list.
prompt.user:
Year: 2010

Paper summary:
Title: GuideCam: A Digital Camera with Picture Spots Finder
Authors: Chiho Watanabe, Itiro Siio, Takayuki Goto, Koji Tsukada
Year: 2010
Abstract: This work addresses integrating a picture-spot finder into a digital camera. The proposal combines smartphone GPS and online photo-sharing service geotags to display candidate shooting locations on a map and uses a user interface with Next/Prev actions and automatic updates to cycle and present the candidates.
Positioning Summary: This research is positioned to address the problem that smartphone users have difficulty finding photo shooting locations. The positioning identifies gaps in consumer GPS devices and online photo-sharing geotags and aims to improve discoverability for photographers.
Purpose Summary: The purpose of this research is to improve shooting efficiency and discoverability by presenting useful candidate locations to photographers. The goal is to leverage smartphones and online photo data to compensate for missing or coarse geotag information and provide candidate suggestions.
Method Summary: The method of this research acquires device GPS and online photo-sharing geotag data and displays candidate shooting spots on a map service. The system implementation displays the collected geotags on a map and provides mechanisms such as Next/Prev actions and automatic updates in the user interface to cycle through candidates.
Evaluation Summary: The evaluation of this research was based on analyzing geotag accuracy using online photo-sharing geotag data and smartphone GPS data. The evaluation analyzed location offsets in the range of hundreds of meters to kilometers and inspected the candidate presentation and map display behavior of the proposed system, suggesting that geotag coarseness causes variability in candidate location accuracy.

Respond with JSON using the following schema:
{
  "ccs": [
    {
      "id": "concept id string",
      "path": "concept path string",
      "confidence": "high|medium|low",
      "justification": "brief reason citing evidence from the paper summary"
    }
  ],
  "rejected": [
    {
      "id": "concept id string",
      "reason": "why it was excluded"
    }
  ]
}
Always use candidate IDs exactly as provided. Do not invent new concepts. Limit the array under "ccs" to at most 3 entries. Limit the array under "rejected" to at most 5 entries. Keep every justification or reason concise (no more than 120 characters).
